trans-unit.source: Node.js web app using the Azure Table Service
trans-unit.target: Node.js web app using the Azure Table Service

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that teaches you how to use the Azure Table service to store data from a Node.js application hosted in Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that teaches you how to use the Azure Table service to store data from a Node.js application hosted in Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Node.js web app using the Azure Table Service
trans-unit.target: Node.js web app using the Azure Table Service

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use Table service provided by Azure Data Management to store and access data from a [node] application hosted in [Azure App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use Table service provided by Azure Data Management to store and access data from a [node] application hosted in [Azure App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you have some prior experience using node and [Git].
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have some prior experience using node and [Git].

trans-unit.source: You will learn:
trans-unit.target: You will learn:

trans-unit.source: How to use npm (node package manager) to install the node modules
trans-unit.target: How to use npm (node package manager) to install the node modules

trans-unit.source: How to work with the Azure Table service
trans-unit.target: How to work with the Azure Table service

trans-unit.source: How to use the Azure CLI to create a web app.
trans-unit.target: How to use the Azure CLI to create a web app.

trans-unit.source: By following this tutorial, you will build a simple web-based "to-do list" application that allows creating, retrieving and completing tasks.
trans-unit.target: By following this tutorial, you will build a simple web-based "to-do list" application that allows creating, retrieving and completing tasks.

trans-unit.source: The tasks are stored in the Table service.
trans-unit.target: The tasks are stored in the Table service.

trans-unit.source: Here is the completed application:
trans-unit.target: Here is the completed application:

trans-unit.source: A web page displaying an empty tasklist
trans-unit.target: A web page displaying an empty tasklist

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before following the instructions in this article, ensure that you have the following installed:
trans-unit.target: Before following the instructions in this article, ensure that you have the following installed:

trans-unit.source: [node] version 0.10.24 or higher
trans-unit.target: [node] version 0.10.24 or higher

trans-unit.source: Git
trans-unit.target: Git

trans-unit.source: Create a storage account
trans-unit.target: Create a storage account

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: The app will use this account to store the to-do items.
trans-unit.target: The app will use this account to store the to-do items.

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click the **New** icon on the bottom left of the portal, then click **Data + Storage** > **Storage**.
trans-unit.target: Click the **New** icon on the bottom left of the portal, then click **Data + Storage** > **Storage**.

trans-unit.source: Give the storage account a unique name and create a new [resource group](../resource-group-overview.md) for it.
trans-unit.target: Give the storage account a unique name and create a new [resource group](../resource-group-overview.md) for it.

trans-unit.source: New Button
trans-unit.target: New Button

trans-unit.source: When the storage account has been created, the **Notifications** button will flash a green **SUCCESS** and the storage account's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.
trans-unit.target: When the storage account has been created, the **Notifications** button will flash a green **SUCCESS** and the storage account's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.

trans-unit.source: In the storage account's blade, click **Settings** > **Keys**.
trans-unit.target: In the storage account's blade, click **Settings** > **Keys**.

trans-unit.source: Copy the primary access key to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Copy the primary access key to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Access key
trans-unit.target: Access key

trans-unit.source: Install modules and generate scaffolding
trans-unit.target: Install modules and generate scaffolding

trans-unit.source: In this section you will create a new Node application and use npm to add module packages.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will create a new Node application and use npm to add module packages.

trans-unit.source: For this application you will use the [Express] and [Azure] modules.
trans-unit.target: For this application you will use the [Express] and [Azure] modules.

trans-unit.source: The Express module provides a Model View Controller framework for node, while the Azure modules provides connectivity to the Table service.
trans-unit.target: The Express module provides a Model View Controller framework for node, while the Azure modules provides connectivity to the Table service.

trans-unit.source: Install express and generate scaffolding
trans-unit.target: Install express and generate scaffolding

trans-unit.source: From the command line, create a new directory named **tasklist** and switch to that directory.
trans-unit.target: From the command line, create a new directory named **tasklist** and switch to that directory.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to install the Express module.
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to install the Express module.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the operating system, you may need to put 'sudo' before the command:
trans-unit.target: Depending on the operating system, you may need to put 'sudo' before the command:

trans-unit.source: The output appears similar to the following example:
trans-unit.target: The output appears similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The '-g' parameter installs the module globally.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The '-g' parameter installs the module globally.

trans-unit.source: That way, we can use **express** to generate web app scaffolding without having to type in additional path information.
trans-unit.target: That way, we can use **express** to generate web app scaffolding without having to type in additional path information.

trans-unit.source: To create the scaffolding for the application, enter the **express** command:
trans-unit.target: To create the scaffolding for the application, enter the **express** command:

trans-unit.target: The output of this command appears similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: You now have several new directories and files in the **tasklist** directory.
trans-unit.target: You now have several new directories and files in the **tasklist** directory.

trans-unit.source: Install additional modules
trans-unit.target: Install additional modules

trans-unit.source: One of the files that **express** creates is **package.json**.
trans-unit.target: One of the files that **express** creates is **package.json**.

trans-unit.source: This file contains a list of module dependencies.
trans-unit.target: This file contains a list of module dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Later, when you deploy the application to App Service Web Apps, this file determines which modules need to be installed on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Later, when you deploy the application to App Service Web Apps, this file determines which modules need to be installed on Azure.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, enter the following command to install the modules described in the **package.json** file.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, enter the following command to install the modules described in the **package.json** file.

trans-unit.target: You may need to use 'sudo'.

trans-unit.target: The output of this command appears similar to the following example:

trans-unit.target: Next, enter the following command to install the [azure], [node-uuid], [nconf] and [async] modules:

trans-unit.source: The **--save** flag adds entries for these modules to the **package.json** file.
trans-unit.target: The **--save** flag adds entries for these modules to the **package.json** file.

trans-unit.target: The output of this command appears similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: Create the application
trans-unit.target: Create the application

trans-unit.source: Now we're ready to build the application.
trans-unit.target: Now we're ready to build the application.

trans-unit.source: Create a model
trans-unit.target: Create a model

trans-unit.source: A *model* is an object that represents the data in your application.
trans-unit.target: A *model* is an object that represents the data in your application.

trans-unit.source: For the application, the only model is a task object, which represents an item in the to-do list.
trans-unit.target: For the application, the only model is a task object, which represents an item in the to-do list.

trans-unit.source: Tasks will have the following fields:
trans-unit.target: Tasks will have the following fields:

trans-unit.source: PartitionKey
trans-unit.target: PartitionKey

trans-unit.source: RowKey
trans-unit.target: RowKey

trans-unit.source: name (string)
trans-unit.target: name (string)

trans-unit.source: category (string)
trans-unit.target: category (string)

trans-unit.source: completed (Boolean)
trans-unit.target: completed (Boolean)

trans-unit.source: **PartitionKey** and **RowKey** are used by the Table Service as table keys.
trans-unit.target: **PartitionKey** and **RowKey** are used by the Table Service as table keys.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Understanding the Table Service data model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179338.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Understanding the Table Service data model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179338.aspx).

trans-unit.source: In the **tasklist** directory, create a new directory named **models**.
trans-unit.target: In the **tasklist** directory, create a new directory named **models**.

trans-unit.source: In the **models** directory, create a new file named **task.js**.
trans-unit.target: In the **models** directory, create a new file named **task.js**.

trans-unit.source: This file will contain the model for the tasks created by your application.
trans-unit.target: This file will contain the model for the tasks created by your application.

trans-unit.source: At the beginning of the **task.js** file, add the following code to reference required libraries:
trans-unit.target: At the beginning of the **task.js** file, add the following code to reference required libraries:

trans-unit.target: Add the following code to define and export the Task object.

trans-unit.source: This object is responsible for connecting to the table.
trans-unit.target: This object is responsible for connecting to the table.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to define additional methods on the Task object, which allow interactions with data stored in the table:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to define additional methods on the Task object, which allow interactions with data stored in the table:

trans-unit.target: Save and close the **task.js** file.

trans-unit.target: Create a controller

trans-unit.target: A *controller* handles HTTP requests and renders the HTML response.

trans-unit.source: Modify the index view
trans-unit.target: Modify the index view

trans-unit.source: Open the **tasklist/views/index.jade** file in a text editor.
trans-unit.target: Open the **tasklist/views/index.jade** file in a text editor.

trans-unit.source: Replace the entire contents of the file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the entire contents of the file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: This defines a view that displays existing tasks and includes a form for adding new tasks and marking existing ones as completed.
trans-unit.target: This defines a view that displays existing tasks and includes a form for adding new tasks and marking existing ones as completed.

trans-unit.source: Save and close **index.jade** file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close **index.jade** file.

trans-unit.source: Modify the global layout
trans-unit.target: Modify the global layout

trans-unit.source: The **layout.jade** file in the **views** directory is a global template for other **.jade** files.
trans-unit.target: The **layout.jade** file in the **views** directory is a global template for other **.jade** files.

trans-unit.source: In this step you will modify it to use [Twitter Bootstrap](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap), which is a toolkit that makes it easy to design a nice looking web app.
trans-unit.target: In this step you will modify it to use [Twitter Bootstrap](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap), which is a toolkit that makes it easy to design a nice looking web app.

trans-unit.source: Download and extract the files for [Twitter Bootstrap](http://getbootstrap.com/).
trans-unit.target: Download and extract the files for [Twitter Bootstrap](http://getbootstrap.com/).

trans-unit.source: Copy the **bootstrap.min.css** file from the Bootstrap **css** folder into the **public/stylesheets** directory of your application.
trans-unit.target: Copy the **bootstrap.min.css** file from the Bootstrap **css** folder into the **public/stylesheets** directory of your application.

trans-unit.source: From the **views** folder, open **layout.jade** and replace the entire contents with the following:
trans-unit.target: From the **views** folder, open **layout.jade** and replace the entire contents with the following:

trans-unit.source: Create a config file
trans-unit.target: Create a config file

trans-unit.source: To run the app locally, we'll put Azure Storage credentials into a config file.
trans-unit.target: To run the app locally, we'll put Azure Storage credentials into a config file.

trans-unit.source: Create a file named **config.json* *with the following JSON:
trans-unit.target: Create a file named **config.json* *with the following JSON:

trans-unit.source: Replace **storage account name** with the name of the storage account you created earlier, and replace **storage access key** with the primary access key for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Replace **storage account name** with the name of the storage account you created earlier, and replace **storage access key** with the primary access key for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Save this file *one directory level higher* than the **tasklist** directory, like this:
trans-unit.target: Save this file *one directory level higher* than the **tasklist** directory, like this:

trans-unit.source: The reason for doing this is to avoid checking the config file into source control, where it might become public.
trans-unit.target: The reason for doing this is to avoid checking the config file into source control, where it might become public.

trans-unit.source: When we deploy the app to Azure, we will use environment variables instead of a config file.
trans-unit.target: When we deploy the app to Azure, we will use environment variables instead of a config file.

trans-unit.source: Run the application locally
trans-unit.target: Run the application locally

trans-unit.source: To test the application on your local machine, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To test the application on your local machine, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the **tasklist** directory.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the **tasklist** directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to launch the application locally:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to launch the application locally:

trans-unit.source: Open a web browser and navigate to http://127.0.0.1:3000.
trans-unit.target: Open a web browser and navigate to http://127.0.0.1:3000.

trans-unit.source: A web page similar to the following example appears.
trans-unit.target: A web page similar to the following example appears.

trans-unit.source: A webpage displaying an empty tasklist
trans-unit.target: A webpage displaying an empty tasklist

trans-unit.source: To create a new to-do item, enter a name and category and click **Add Item**.
trans-unit.target: To create a new to-do item, enter a name and category and click **Add Item**.

trans-unit.source: To mark a task as complete, check **Complete** and click **Update Tasks**.
trans-unit.target: To mark a task as complete, check **Complete** and click **Update Tasks**.

trans-unit.source: An image of the new item in the list of tasks
trans-unit.target: An image of the new item in the list of tasks

trans-unit.source: Even though the application is running locally, it is storing the data in the Azure Table service.
trans-unit.target: Even though the application is running locally, it is storing the data in the Azure Table service.

trans-unit.source: Deploy your application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy your application to Azure

trans-unit.source: The steps in this section use the Azure command-line tools to create a new web app in App Service, and then use Git to deploy your application.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this section use the Azure command-line tools to create a new web app in App Service, and then use Git to deploy your application.

trans-unit.source: To perform these steps you must have an Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: To perform these steps you must have an Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] These steps can also be performed by using the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] These steps can also be performed by using the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: See [Build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure App Service].
trans-unit.target: See [Build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure App Service].

trans-unit.source: If this is the first web app you have created, you must use the Azure Portal to deploy this application.
trans-unit.target: If this is the first web app you have created, you must use the Azure Portal to deploy this application.

trans-unit.source: To get started, install the [Azure CLI] by entering the following command from the command line:
trans-unit.target: To get started, install the [Azure CLI] by entering the following command from the command line:

trans-unit.source: Import publishing settings
trans-unit.target: Import publishing settings

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will download a file containing information about your subscription.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will download a file containing information about your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: This command launches a browser and navigates to the download page.
trans-unit.target: This command launches a browser and navigates to the download page.

trans-unit.source: If prompted, log in with the account associated with your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If prompted, log in with the account associated with your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: The file download begins automatically; if it does not, you can click the link at the beginning of the page to manually download the file.
trans-unit.target: The file download begins automatically; if it does not, you can click the link at the beginning of the page to manually download the file.

trans-unit.source: Save the file and note the file path.
trans-unit.target: Save the file and note the file path.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to import the settings:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to import the settings:

trans-unit.source: Specify the path and file name of the publishing settings file you downloaded in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: Specify the path and file name of the publishing settings file you downloaded in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: After the settings are imported, delete the publish settings file.
trans-unit.target: After the settings are imported, delete the publish settings file.

trans-unit.source: It is no longer needed, and contains sensitive information regarding your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: It is no longer needed, and contains sensitive information regarding your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Create an App Service web app
trans-unit.target: Create an App Service web app

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the **tasklist** directory.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the **tasklist** directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to create a new web app.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to create a new web app.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for the web app name and location.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for the web app name and location.

trans-unit.source: Provide a unique name and select the same geographical location as your Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Provide a unique name and select the same geographical location as your Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: The `--git` parameter creates a Git repository on Azure for this web app.
trans-unit.target: The `--git` parameter creates a Git repository on Azure for this web app.

trans-unit.source: It also initializes a Git repository in the current directory if none exists, and adds a [Git remote] named 'azure', which is used to publish the application to Azure.
trans-unit.target: It also initializes a Git repository in the current directory if none exists, and adds a [Git remote] named 'azure', which is used to publish the application to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Finally, it creates a **web.config** file, which contains settings used by Azure to host node applications.
trans-unit.target: Finally, it creates a **web.config** file, which contains settings used by Azure to host node applications.

trans-unit.source: If you omit the `--git` parameter but the directory contains a Git repository, the command will still create the 'azure' remote.
trans-unit.target: If you omit the `--git` parameter but the directory contains a Git repository, the command will still create the 'azure' remote.

trans-unit.source: Once this command has completed, you will see output similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: Once this command has completed, you will see output similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: Note that the line beginning with **Website created at** contains the URL for the web app.
trans-unit.target: Note that the line beginning with **Website created at** contains the URL for the web app.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If this is the first App Service web app for your subscription, you will be instructed to use the Azure Portal to create the web app.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If this is the first App Service web app for your subscription, you will be instructed to use the Azure Portal to create the web app.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure App Service].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure App Service].

trans-unit.source: Set environment variables
trans-unit.target: Set environment variables

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will add environment variables to your web app configuration on Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will add environment variables to your web app configuration on Azure.

trans-unit.source: From the command line, enter the following:
trans-unit.target: From the command line, enter the following:

trans-unit.source: Replace **<storage account name>** with the name of the storage account you created earlier, and replace **<storage access key>** with the primary access key for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Replace **<storage account name>** with the name of the storage account you created earlier, and replace **<storage access key>** with the primary access key for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: (Use the same values as the config.json file that you created earlier.)
trans-unit.target: (Use the same values as the config.json file that you created earlier.)

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can set environment variables in the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com):
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can set environment variables in the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com):

trans-unit.source: Open the web app's blade by clicking **Browse** > **Web Apps** > your web app name.
trans-unit.target: Open the web app's blade by clicking **Browse** > **Web Apps** > your web app name.

trans-unit.source: In your web app's blade, click **All Settings** > **Application Settings**.
trans-unit.target: In your web app's blade, click **All Settings** > **Application Settings**.

trans-unit.source: Scroll down to the **App settings** section and add the key/value pairs.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down to the **App settings** section and add the key/value pairs.

trans-unit.source: App Settings
trans-unit.target: App Settings

trans-unit.source: Click **SAVE**.
trans-unit.target: Click **SAVE**.

trans-unit.source: Publish the application
trans-unit.target: Publish the application

trans-unit.source: To publish the app, commit the code files to Git and then push to azure/master.
trans-unit.target: To publish the app, commit the code files to Git and then push to azure/master.

trans-unit.source: Set your deployment credentials.
trans-unit.target: Set your deployment credentials.

trans-unit.source: Add and commit your application files.
trans-unit.target: Add and commit your application files.

trans-unit.source: Push the commit to the App Service web app:
trans-unit.target: Push the commit to the App Service web app:

trans-unit.source: Use **master** as the target branch.
trans-unit.target: Use **master** as the target branch.

trans-unit.source: At the end of the deployment, you see a statement similar to the following example:
trans-unit.target: At the end of the deployment, you see a statement similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: Once the push operation has completed, browse to the web app URL returned previously by the `azure create site` command to view your application.
trans-unit.target: Once the push operation has completed, browse to the web app URL returned previously by the `azure create site` command to view your application.

trans-unit.source: While the steps in this article describe using the Table Service to store information, you can also use MongoDB.
trans-unit.target: While the steps in this article describe using the Table Service to store information, you can also use MongoDB.

trans-unit.source: See [Node.js web app with MongoDB] for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [Node.js web app with MongoDB] for more information.
